title: Lexeme
description: A lexeme is used broadly by DLx to refer to any collection of related senses and forms, whether the item is an individual word, a construction, a morpheme, or even a fully-inflected phrase. In other words, DLx lexeme objects can be used to describe anything that constitutes a lexical unit or memorized chunk. A lexeme will often have multiple *senses* or meanings, and those are listed in the `senses` field. It is up to the linguist to decide when two meanings are related, and therefore part of the same lexeme, or when they belong in different lexemes. A lexeme will also often have multiple forms, even before considering inflection. For example, the lexeme `run` in English has two base forms: `run` and `ran`. These different base forms of a lexeme are listed in the `forms` field. The `baseForms` field should *not* be used to list all the inflectional forms of a lexeme.

citationForm.title: Citation Form
citationForm.description: A citation form is the form of a word when given in isolation, which may be different from its lemma form. For example, in English the citation form of a verb is typically the infinitive, e.g. `to run`, even though the lemma form of the word is simply `run`.
